ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments:
Breakout rooms with problem worksheets
Recorded pre-class videos introducing lecture content
watch pre-recorded videos and practice in synchronous class
No other modes of learning.
weekly p-sets, quizzes and exams
recorded lecture
This was a section for Math 112 and was a combination of a lecture and breakout rooms.
Professor Diethorn would teach a concept in the beginning of our zoom classes and then we would go into breakout rooms with small groups to do a practice worksheet.
pre-class videos
Going over topics at the beginning of class and completing worksheets with classmates for the second half of class.
This class was live with a recorded lecture aspect.
Office hours
Live lectures were typically recorded.
I also watched the lectures if I missed them.
None
There were live lectures during the week and recorded lectures available for referral after the lecture.
They were live virtual lectures that were recorded.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I understood the basics of calculus even better than I did in highschool.

Skills
- working with others to solve problems and help one another 
Insights
- remote learning is not impossible if given the right circumstances
Knowledge
- refresher on content learnt in highschool with a lot of clarity
I learned about limits, continuity, derivatives, optimization, integrals, differentials.

I learned the fundamentals of calculus of functions of a single variable! Perhaps more importantly I learned how to solve problems and how to ask questions when I didn't know how to solve them myself.
derivatives and some integration knowledge
Just your typical math course. Learned what would be considered calculus AB in high school.
Foundational calculus topics
I learned about Calculus I topics essentially derivatives, integrals, and differential equations.
We covered all topics from Calc 1 and learned how to compute derivatives and integrals.
Calculus
I learned how to take a wider approach to answering problems.
How to attend office hours effectively, critical thinking skills
A good grasp on calculus, from integrals, derivatives, differential equations, etc. and math modeling.
I developed critical thinking skills in the realm of calculus and applied those skills to the solving of questions related to the mastery of various concepts within the course.
I learned the basics of Math 112 including the topics of limits and derivatives.
Basic math review.
How to solve calculus questions accurately and thoroughly.
I developed a greater understanding of fundamental math skills as well as better ways to present my work and findings explicitly.

I further developed my knowledge of foundational Calculus skills and learned how to apply them to word problems and other examples. I developed the ability to use derivatives to solve problems quickly and efficiently as well as using its definition to learn more about why derivatives and other concepts work.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The class is very interactive and fosters student collaboration.

Strengths
- break out rooms
- pre-cass videos
- smaller lecture groups

Weaknesses
- grading system

strengths: lots of support (professors and peer tutors have office hours), assignments and canvas pages pretty well organized
weaknesses: the pre-recorded lectures are too fast and it's hard to understand it (in other words you must read the textbook chapter if you want to really grasp the concepts), it was bad that James Barnes had to do everything (manage piazza, grade HAMs and quizzes, etc). In this way he didn't have time to explain things clearly enough and just neglected a lot of things though I can't blame him.

The strengths of this class were the mastery based grading system and the flipped classroom format. 
The weaknesses were the weekly quizzes. We didn't upload any work and received little feedback on our answers.
the teacher is really nice
The content is good. I thought my instructor did a good job. The flipped learning was new but easy to adjust to for the most part. I really liked that the lectures were recorded.
This year we did not have exams which made the work much more manageable.

One of the greatest strengths of this course was the mastery-based grading. It was really helpful to be able to retake quizzes. One of the weaknesses was communication/feedback there was a quiz that I did not master, and I never received clear feedback on what I was missing.

I feel like the questions on the PSets were not always the same level as the questions given in class. Some involved physics with which I am not too familiar. It is hard to learn math virtually, but the Professor was always available to help.
There was no big test that I had to spend a lot of time studying for. Everything was tested in small increments.
This course could be improved by having actual live quizzes/tests.  It would require students to be more alert and prepared.

Strength - loved the mastery based grading, literally so amazing 

Weakness - more time on canvas quizzes, more office hours later in the day

The mastery based grading was quite nice, because you got to know what subjects you mastered instead of thinking of grades. I think that naturally meant you were gonna get a good grade if you were working for mastery.

I enjoyed that this course had a group work component. Classes were split up into group work and lectures. The group work helped keep me engaged and helped me meet other people. I also liked the grading system. The levels of mastery were reasonable to accomplish and encouraged a growth mindset in the class.

Strengths: a lot of support in class and very collaborative
Weaknesses: not much support outside of class
Hard ti understand how the grading worked. It was never really explained.
I really liked the flipped classroom layout and the mastery based grading system.  It allowed for less concern about the grade and a higher focus of actually understanding the topics presented.

I think the mastery grading system needs better explanation. It was rather difficult to understand what I was being assessed on. The habit of mind skills were hard to understand what exactly the professors were looking for. Also, more comments on assessments and problem sets handed in would be helpful instead of just stating which questions were wrong.

The strengths of this course are that it is very manageable with the workload and has many resources for help when needed. The weakness of the course is that the grading system is difficult to understand at first, but becomes easier over time. The course can be improved with more clear answers from the instructors and responsive actions when the course nears the end of the semester.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Using zoom was helpful in terms of learning but jamboard was not really helpful. I never used it and I was still able to work with my group efficiently.
Breakout rooms were amazing to practice content and make friends remotely
I think having students watch pre-recorded videos and going over them briefly in zoom class and doing practice was helpful

The grading system was created in response to Covid, and it was really beneficial to my learning. We were tested multiple times on each subject, which meant you had multiple opportunities to get something wrong, study, and try again. The breakout rooms in Zoom were also a great additional.It was nice to have a consistent group of peers to do math with. The peer tutors were also so helpful!
office hours were great to ask questions
I liked that the lectures were also recorded. I liked the videos before each class and that the instructor also went over it during class because then we saw it twice before practicing.
The elimination of midterms was very helpful considering COVID-19.

I liked how the professor put us into breakout rooms so that we could work with each other to work on problems, which definitely facilitated virtual engagement. There isn't really much that could be improved in terms of learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, since it is greatly outside of the instructors' control.

I found that what we went over in class wasn't very helpful towards working through the problem sets.  During class, we only had time to go through the first half of the worksheets, which tending to be the easier material.  The problem sets contained the harder material, and it required much more thought and preparation to approach the problem sets.

Mastery based grading succeeded, it gave me control over my own education. 

Better TA's, Kexin was amazing, but also sometimes I would go to TA's and they would not explain stuff very well.
Mastery-based grading and office hours.
The group component of the course helped me improve. Working through problems with peers helped me meet new people and solve any lingering problems I had with the material.
I don't think it would have been much better or worse in person. Professor Diethor often asked us to ask questions which made it much easier to learn.
The in class practice was very helpful so we got a chance to work in a group to solve questions together.  I thought the videos that we learned from were a little too short and not thorough enough.

I really liked how we were placed into breakout rooms to work on worksheets for a good portion of the class after learning. I was able to right away apply what I learned and ask questions when I struggled. The breakout rooms also allowed me to meet people in my class since that was a struggle in quite a few of my other courses.
The course practices geared toward COVID-19 all succeeded. The ability to share the screen and share files allowed for this class to be engaging with the lectures and worksheets for students.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yeah. If you didn't understand the fundamentals of calculus, this is the course for you because it goes into all of them from scratch. It's also really slow-paced, allowing you to take your time to understand things.
Yes, it is important content that is taught such that the content is not extremely difficult to grasp.
yes! I think calculus is a basic and foundational skill to have. but don't expect this class to change your life also
I definitely would! The material is challenging but accessible to everyone. It also satisfied my pre-med requirement for calculus which is a bonus!
absolutely because it gives an insight into the world of calculus
Yeah I think this is a good basic math course.
If you enjoy math or need this course as a prereq or major requirement.

I probably would not recommend this course to another student. I would only recommend it to them if they are struggling in Math 115, or need calculus as a requirement. Otherwise, I would suggest taking a different course to fulfill the QR requirement.
Yes! Math 112 is a great introductory calc course and the workload is manageable. The professors and peer tutors are available multiple times per week for help.
Yes, it was a good math class that didn't have a high workload.
I would recommend this course to any student looking to learn the basics of calculus at a fast pace.
I would. Enjoyed the class,  not terrible. Supported pretty well, teachers were nice.
Yes, this course was great! Professor Barnes, the overall Math 112 professor, utilized the mastery based grading very well, and Professor Diethorn is a very good lecturer and teacher!
Yes, I would recommend this course because the instructors and peer tutors made the material interesting. Further, they made it enjoyable to engage with the material and learn the concepts.

Yes, I would. It was a clear class and a great introduction to math at Yale. I would recommend it to people who have already taken calculus because it was a good refresher course to get ready for Math 115.
Yes, it is a lot of work but it is manageable if you understand the material.
Yes, good basic knowledge.
Yes, the grading system was very helpful and improved my learning throughout the semester.

I would. The course covers a the fundamentals of calculus in great detail and ensures that there is enough practice worksheets, problem sets and assessments that I learned and understood all of the topics thoroughly.

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. This course is an excellent introduction to calculus and math at Yale. There are a wide variety of resources that are available for students to receive help when needed. Overall, I recommend the course if you are placed for the math credit or want to learn more about calculus.
